title: 110_s2119
content: The Act is titled the "American Veterans Disabled for Life Commemorative Coin Act". The Congress acknowledges the service and sacrifices of the Armed Forces, including those who have served in World War II, Korea, Vietnam, and the Middle East. Americans are urged to honor both living disabled veterans and those who have made the ultimate sacrifice for their country. Congress authorized the construction of the American Veterans Disabled for Life Memorial in 2000. The United States should honor living disabled veterans by issuing a commemorative silver dollar coin, with proceeds going towards the construction of the American Veterans Disabled for Life Memorial. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint $1 silver coins in honor of disabled American veterans, with specific weight, diameter, and composition. The coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of the coins will be determined. The design of the coins minted under this Act will be emblematic of the design selected by the Disabled Veterans' LIFE Memorial Foundation for the American Veterans Disabled for Life Memorial. Each coin will have a value designation, the year "2010" inscribed, and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Disabled Veterans' LIFE Memorial Foundation and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design of the coins minted under this Act will be emblematic of the design selected by the Disabled Veterans' LIFE Memorial Foundation for the American Veterans Disabled for Life Memorial. The design will be reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at the United States Mint at West Point, New York. The Secretary may issue coins only during the calendar year beginning on January 1, 2010. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, surcharge, and cost of designing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales of coins issued under this Act include a $10 surcharge per coin, with the surcharges going to the Disabled Veterans' LIFE Memorial Foundation for the construction of the American Veterans' Disabled for Life Memorial in Washington, D.C. The Comptroller General of the United States has the right to audit the Foundation's expenditures related to these surcharges. No surcharge may be included for any coin issuance in a calendar year if the issuance has already occurred. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance to limit the number of commemorative coin programs issued in a calendar year to avoid exceeding the annual issuance limitation.
